Wissam Ben Yedder has a big offer from China, but wants to move to a top European club

However, TF1 report that the likelihood of him taking one of these offers up is minimal, as he wants to join a top European club to further his chances of being at EURO 2020 next summer.

The 28-year-old has been informed that Beijing Guoan are willing and ready to activate his €40m release clause and that the Chinese Super League club are willing to offer him €12m a year on a long term contract. Nicolas Pépé chooses Arsenal

La Voix du Nord report this evening that Nicolas Pépé has chosen to move to Arsenal.

A source close to Lille told them today that the Ivorian attacker has basically fully made his decision. Unless a last minute bid comes in from PSG, which seems highly improbable, the player should join Arsenal on Tuesday or Wednesday.

Arsenal have met both the player and his agents’ demands, whereas Napoli are understood not to have done so as fully.

The choice is understood to have been narrowed down to being between the Gunners and Napoli.

Lille are still working on a replacement for Nicolas Pépé - negotiations for Dodi Lukebakio (Watford), Adam Ounas (Napoli) & Yusuf Yazici (Trabzonspor) have all fallen through, according to La Voix du Nord.

Arsenal have reached a similar agreement with St.Etienne for teenage centre-half William Saliba, who will eventually cost them £27million but only around £6million this year.

That means that the club are still working within their £50million summer budget, which has been slightly boosted by the sales of David Ospina and Xavier Amaechi.

Fuming Mauricio Pochettino claims he is no longer in charge of transfers at Tottenham and called for his title to be changed from manager to coach:

“Maybe the club need to change my title description now, because my job now is to coach the team.”

Pochettino: “[Transfers] not a question for me, they are a question for the club, maybe they are going to change my title description.”

I’m not in charge of this. I know nothing about the situation of my players, I’m only coaching, trying to get the best from them.”

Pochettino: “This type of things, are going to happen or not happen, sell, buy players, extend contracts or not extend contracts, it’s not in my hands, it’s in the club’s hands and in Daniel’s hands. At the moment I’m just managing the team in the best way possible.”

Hertha Berlin overtake Lille in the race for Dodi Lukebakio

L’Équipe and Foot Mercato report that Bundesliga side Hertha Berlin have now overtaken and are set to beat Lille in the race for Watford’s Belgian winger Dodi Lukebakio.

Les Dogues had an initial €12m + €3m in bonuses offer rejected by the Premier League side for the player, and considered upping their bid in recent days for the 21-year-old.

However, Hertha Berlin’s offer is €20m and Les Dogues were unconvinced about competing at that level. Lukebakio’s preference was Lille, excited about the prospect of playing Champions’ League football, but Hertha now appear to have won the race.

Watford of course were keen to push the player in that direction, and despite renewed fee discussions in recent days, LOSC do not appear set to improve their bid. In Germany, Lukebakio now appears set to sign a 5-year contract.

Amiens reject opening €5m Newcastle bid for Emil Krafth

Outlet Soccer Link, who have very good links to Ligue 1 side Amiens, are reporting that the club in question have rejected an opening bid from Premier League side Newcastle United worth €5m for 24-year-old versatile Swedish right-sided defender Emil Krafth.

Steve Bruce is understood to want the player because of his versatility and his strength in duels, and wants to close a deal rapidly.

Newcastle see Krafth as the ideal competitor for DeAndre Yedlin for the starting right-back berth and will imminently make an improved bid.

The 26-year-old remains a priority for ASM, who want to sell Djibril Sidibé first before concluding a deal. Aguilar is under contract with MHSC until 2020 and ASM may have to move fast, as the usual Premier League last-minute panic sets in.

Everyone knows how that worked out for Fulham, as Seri, Schurrle and Co. sent Fulham straight back to the Championship.

But to understand why Aston Villa have spent so much, and why what they are doing is very different from Fulham, you have to look at their side last season.

Over thirty-five million dollars of Villa’s transfer war chest was spent buying players that were on loan at Villa Park last season. Fulham’s spending destabilized the club, but Aston Villa’s spending is partly to keep their squad stable.

A huge part of Aston Villa’s success last season was their midfield trio of Jack Grealish, John McGinn and Conor Hourihane, so unsurprisingly Dean Smith hasn’t overhauled his central midfield.

Villa’s loan signings were also vital in helping them earn promotion from the Championship. Yannick Bolasie for the first half of the season and Anwar El Ghazi for the second half helped create the opportunities for Tammy Abraham to score 25 goals last season. At the back, Axel Tuanzebe and Tyrone Mings provided a reasonably solid central defensive partnership (although Villa shipped a lot more goals than many of their promotion rivals.)

Aston Villa made the transfers of Mings and El Ghazi permanent this summer, but Abraham has returned to Chelsea and Tuanzebe to Manchester United. Tuanzebe has been replaced by Ezri Konsa, a player that current Villa manager Dean Smith knows well from his time in charge of Brentford.

https://www.forbes.com/sites/steveprice/2019/07/22/why-aston-villa-needed-to-spend-spend-spend-this-summer/#1fd32c227189

Allan Saint Maximin to Newcastle, final details

RMC and Soccer Link report that Premier League side Newcastle United have today concluded an agreement with Ligue 1 club OGC Nice to sign 22-year-old French youth international winger Allan Saint-Maximin.

Lee Charnley led a Newcastle delegation in talks with Les Aiglons today in Nice to complete a deal, which is €18m + a set of considerable bonuses, with €4m of those bonuses said to be easily obtainable.

Saint-Maximin has already agreed personal terms over a 6-year contract with the Magpies.

This was NUFC’s 3rd formal offer, having had bids worth €16m and €18m knocked back respectively.

The move to Arsenal obviously somewhat negates what Pépé set out to achieve: play Champions’ League football. But as Domenighetti wrote today, more important than these objectives was the idea of becoming a key player in a club at a level above Lille.

Whilst Liverpool clearly enticed him, another highly-respected French journalist has since told Get French Football News that LFC’s inability to offer Pépé consistent playing time brought an end to talks before they reached an advanced stage, despite Jurgen Klopp’s enormous desire to sign the Ivorian.

https://www.getfootballnewsfrance.com/2019/how-lille-played-the-market-to-get-e80m-for-nicolas-pepe/

Plenty have questioned all summer why a CB has not been top priority at #AFC given recent seasons...

A: The club's analysis team pinpointed the need for more pace and skill in attack as the best way of improving poor away form, which is why Zaha & Pepe were targeted instead.

Bild last night reported that Bayern Munich had submitted offers to both Manchester City and Sané.

More follows.
